title: Biglerville soccer team honors memory of Meghan McKinney
text:
Biglerville soccer team honors memory of Meghan McKinney Students, friends, coaches and family came together to remember McKinney, who loved sports and animals 
By Davin Jurgensen 
djurgensen@eveningsun.com @davinjurgensen on Twitter Posted: 10/08/2015 09:11:25 PM EDT Biglerville athletes react after the ceremony on the field Oct. 8 honoring the life of Meghan McKinney, a Biglerville High School alum who died in a car crash last week. (Clare Becker — The Evening Sun) Biglerville Class of 2009 alumn Chaney Musgrave, left, watches the tribute from the side of the field at Biglerville High School on Oct. 8. (Clare Becker — The Evening Sun) 
The Biglerville High School soccer team took the field Thursday night. 
This time, though, each player was holding a yellow carnation as they gathered in the center. 
The flowers were a tribute to Meghan McKinney, a 23-year-old Biglerville alum, who died last week in a five-vehicle crash on Interstate 283. 
Players, coaches and members of McKinney's family held hands in a circle for a moment of silence. 
Danielle Cramer, head soccer coach at Biglerville High School, organized the tribute Thursday night before the soccer game. 
She coached McKinney all four years, she said, and they still kept in touch. 
"We had plans for the Friday after she passed," Cramer said. 
McKinney, a Biglerville native, was big on sports, playing not only soccer, but field hockey and basketball, said her mother, Kim Killen. 
But she was more than an athlete. She had a dream of owning an animal rescue. 
McKinney worked at an Adams County pet store and took care of the dogs as if they were her own, Killen said. 
Killen found an old memory card from her daughter's camera with pictures of mission trips she took to India and the Dominican Republic. 
"All I saw were photos of stray dogs," she said. "She just wanted to save them all." 
One of McKinney's friends from high school, Alysia Fair, said McKinney was a dog whisperer. 
"My dog hated everybody but her," Fair said. Advertisement 
McKinney also developed a love for nursing after graduating with an athletic training degree from Slippery Rock University in 2014. 
This August, McKinney started a 16-month nursing degree program at Penn State Harrisburg, Killen said. She would have graduated in December 2016. 
"She just got her stethoscopes a couple weeks ago," her mother said. "She was excited to start her career; she was taking my blood pressure and everything." 
McKinney was on her way to school the day of the crash, Killen said. Meghan McKinney's mother, Kim Killen, forms a circle on the field with loved ones and Biglerville staff and students during a moment of silence in remembrance of her daughter, Meghan McKinney, on Oct. 8. (Clare Becker — The Evening Sun) 
It involved a pickup truck with a camper trailer, a commercial tractor-trailer and three other vehicles, including a Ford Escape driven by McKinney, according to a release from Pennsylvania State Police. The crash occurred on Interstate 283 in Lower Swatara Township, police said. 
Killen is thankful for the GoFundMe fundraising site that was started in honor of her daughter, but says she isn't taking a dime. 
"That money will be given to animal rescues," she said. "It's what Meghan would want." 
McKinney left an impact on many people, including her eighth-grade math teacher at Upper Adams Middle School, Stephanie Staub. 
The bond they formed left McKinney to visit her once a week, if not every day, while in school, she said. 
But the visits continued even after McKinney left for college, stopping by whenever she came home. 
"I have two boys, and she was kind of like my girl," Staub said. "We were able to talk, joke, cry and laugh together." 
Staub could've been angry about something, but when McKinney walked in with "one of the best smiles," she would feel better. 
Staub also remembers McKinney for her big bear hugs. 
"I cherish the relationship we had. It was a privilege and an honor to have been part of her life," Staub said. "She's one of those kids you'll never, ever forget." 
The tribute Thursday ended with those on the field coming in for a sportsman-like cheer to start the game. 
And as hands raised on the count of three, the players shouted Meghan's name. Previous coverage
